Message.Title: this week, oct 14th
Message.Msg: This week, Oct 14 Fewer sponsors than usual, no rich people car ads, two from IBM and BP, Schwab for the investment inclined, Pacific Life, Dell, that is about it. No In memoriam or mention of USA military deaths in Afghanistan. There was editorial comment about the GOP (Romney) receiving good press and higher attendance at events in Ohio, and its Senator (rob Portman) labelling the Obama campaign as quite negative. What happened in Benghazi was said (by Portman) as not caused by a movie trailer, but was a highly organized Sept 11 event. And of course GOP doing great in Ohio, feels Portman. Again, the VP is quoted saying “we” did not know of security needs in Libya. Others in adm, though, did… Bulk of program dealing with query, “Do presidential campaign debates matter?” We heard re 1960, 1976, Reagan’s “there you go again” in 1980, also his “wont take advantage of youth of opponent 4 years later” and the unemotional Dukakis answer to “if your wife was raped…” And historian g f Will told us the Lincoln Douglas debate included one of 60 minute introductory statement by one, followed by 90 minute replay, then responses to those 150 minutes. Martha Raddatz, moderator of the VP debate, did say she could sense wheels turning as each candidate pondered what might be said, what might have been left out in earlier comments. Jake Tapper filled in for Geo Stephanopoulos.

Topic.Title: 23 Days Until the Re-Election of President Obama

Message.Msg: As an independent I considered Romney seriously. That included character, life achievements, politics, demeanor, intelligence, and behavior. Obama disappointed me in several ways. His most apparent lack seems to be promising too much based on his idealism and trust that even known political realities can be easily overcome. Said to say all that is very aggressively exploited and he is demonized by the very same party that gave up most of the financial woes of our times. However, Obama is still a genuine and somebody that I can trust more than Romney with a record of flip flops on basic issues and apparently lacking an inner guidance (at his age?) on major issues yet showing the illusion of being decisive. His debating skills are good but that has little to do with governance of a nation such as ours. His career has limited relevance to what the job requires and his reference of not caring for the 47% Americans is stating how he feels. Simply the GWB/GOP acted irresponsibly and therefore can no more be trusted with the economy... as they still believe in failed policies. Sorry, but I believe Romney has no chance of being elected. The bottom line is that I have no choice but vote for Obama and his idealism is also diminishing. I was wrong in voting for GWB in 2000... I know I am right this time... and Obama is the right choice.

Topic.Title: Republican platform bad, Candidate worse.

Message.Msg: They won't need the voter suppression laws. They will just kidnap voters and lock up enough voters to swing the elections. William Koch allegedly held a senior executive of his Oxbow energy company captive after discovering his concerns with a plan the official claimed in a lawsuit sought to evade U.S. taxes on $200 million in profit. Former Oxbow Senior Vice President Kirby Martensen alleged an internal company probe revealed his misgivings over a plan by Oxbow Carbon & Minerals LLC to evade taxes. As a result, Martensen claimed, he was falsely imprisoned for almost two days by Koch’s agents and interrogated at a remote Colorado ranch as part of an effort to intimidate him. He was also fired, he said. Koch, who Forbes estimates is worth close to $4 billion, is the brother of conservative Tea Party funders David Koch and Charles Koch. Martensen, promoted last year to senior vice president of Oxbow, said he was lured to the billionaire’s Bear Ranch near Aspen in March on false pretenses and questioned about anonymous allegations of wrongdoing against him tied to a kickback scheme, and a related investigation by the firm. “Based on this surreptitious review of plaintiff’s e-mails and voice communications, Koch learned that Martensen and others expressed concern of the legality of what they were doing on behalf of Oxbow and their distrust of upper management,” Martensen said in his complaint filed Oct. 11 in San Francisco federal court. “As a result, William Koch promoted and implemented a plan to intimidate and discredit plaintiff for the purpose of chilling his speech and damaging his credibility.” TOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO FUNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNY!!

Message.Title: UK Meteorological Center saying Global Warming has stopped
Message.Msg: A report quietly published by the UK meteorological department has revealed that global warming stopped 16 years ago with no discernible rise in aggregate global temperature, Daily Mail reported on Sunday. The data, compiled from more than 3,000 measuring points on land and sea, noted that the “plateau” or “pause” in global warming has now lasted for about the same time as the previous period when temperature rose from 1980 to 1996. The Daily Mail report quoted climate scientists – some argued that 15-16 years was too short a period to draw conclusions from, while others said that it was clear that the computer models used to predict future global warming were ‘deeply flawed’. Professor Phil Jones, director of the Climatic Research Unit at the University of East Anglia, admitted that he and his colleagues did not understand the impact of ‘natural variability’, but he was convinced that the current decade would end up significantly warmer than the previous two, the report added. The report quoted other climate scientists who said that the computer models used by the Met Office are flawed and that the climate is far more complex than the models assert. Professor Judith Curry, chair of School of Earth and Atmospheric Science at America’s Georgia Tech university, was quoted as saying, “Climate models are very complex, but they are imperfect and incomplete. Natural variability [the impact of factors such as long-term temperature cycles in the oceans and the output of the sun] has been shown over the past two decades to have a magnitude that dominates the greenhouse warming effect. “It is becoming increasingly apparent that our attribution of warming since 1980 and future projections of climate change needs to consider natural internal variability as a factor of fundamental importance.”
